reviewText: In a non-descript storage facility in the suburbs sit two mysterious machines, the culmination of a group of friend’s hard work, of their nights, of their weekends, of as much capital as they could muster. Then they discover something shocking, they’ve created time machines.The question of what do with these machines arises. At first it seems the machines may be commercially valuable, but this proves false. This is when the inventors turn towards using the machines to benefit themselves.One inventor is conscientious from the beginning, while the other inventor is more adventurous. One inventor is wary of the potential dangers while the other inventor ignores them. They both profess their not wanting to alter the past, but each has a different level of commitment to the subject. They both try to keep the project quiet, under wraps from world, but things easily get out of control amongst themselves. Aghast at their errors, they try to set things right, but since time travel functions according unknown sets of laws different from those of linear time, the concocted logical solutions to their problem end up becoming just additional steps towards disaster.Supposedly made for only $7000, this film is a marvel. Not only is it a fascinating story, the camera work and the production value are very good. With long scenes, and thoughtful performances by the cast, this quasi Sci-fi/Arthouse film is a visual pleasure to watch. It doesn’t screen as a low budget thriller.While Director/Writer Shane Carruth’s vision isn’t exactly crystal clear, this mystery is part of the charm. For a film about a complex subject like time travel, the success is in Carruth’s ability to purvey the concept with very little flare. Everything seems to have aligned perfectly here. That is not to say it is the greatest film ever, but for a movie about such complicated subject matter, the bare-bones approach is very interesting. The script and characters talk about what they know. A narrator fills us in on a few more key details. Then the rest we are left to figure out on our own. As a sci-fi thriller this film works very well.7/10Get more at getthebonesaw.blogspot.com

reviewText: I like a challenge, but this is one of the most confusing movies of all time. Despite its brevity, looping plot, and highfalutin physics dialogue, Primer (2004) still comes away a winner in my book.I am not sure if this movie's circularity actually makes sense. Really. (Chuck Klosterman is said to have seen it seven or eight times and is still not sure what transpired.) The basic premise is that a group of four dudes accidentally invent a time machine in a garage while spending their spare time after their day jobs working on computer hardware. Aaron, the married guy with the garage, and Abe, his single friend, decide to keep the discovery a secret from the two other dudes.If only they could keep the secret from their past selves (or is it future selves?).  Abe decides to fashion a desk-sized version of their first television-sized time travel box. And this is where the movie gets really interesting, raising all kinds of philosophical and existential issues along the way about time and space, morality, and reality.I don't want to give too much away, but let's just say that Abe and Aaron start to travel through time. Like any red-blooded American males that have moved beyond college and into the working world, the guys predictably use time travel schemes to boost their financial situations. They exploit the stock market. But, things become less than kosher and fancy free when trust breaks down between Abe and Aaron.The final 15 minutes of this movie are a head-scratcher. There is so much looping and nefarious backstabbing going on between Abe, Aaron, and their "time doubles" that I could not follow it. Wikipedia has a nice diagram that explains the time travel device and how it works; I can't understand that, either. I walked away feeling that the creator of this movie is very intelligent, but not in a way that allows him to leave the average viewer (i.e., me) walking away feeling victorious for figuring out the M.C. Escher maze that was laid out. Good luck.I am a fan of short movies, and at 78 minutes Primer is a miracle of efficiency. But, the pithiness of the film was a product of necessity and a small bankroll, so it is possible that my gripes about the last 15 minutes might have been lessened if the director/actor/writer/producer/cameraman in charge of this picture had more film stock to work with. Just another 10 minutes might have relaxed the breakneck pace and confusing looping in the last 15 minutes.One of the most incredible aspects of this film is that it was produced on a $7,000 budget, most of it dedicated to film stock. In the first five to 10 minutes of action, you'll note that the cinematography and sound are not up to big studio snuff. The dialogue seems to overlap, and the acting is wooden. After the time machine is discovered and the plot really kicks into gear, the brilliant story takes over and you forget about the amateur, low-budget feel. You relate to the protagonists, placing yourself into their shoes and considering the implications of the "fun" that time travel could provide before the complications rear their ugly heads. The middle of this movie is the satisfying thought-provoker, the beginning the underwhelming physics lesson, and the ending a mystifying quagmire.Primer works if you go in with a little knowledge of the plot, have already slogged through movies like Memento and Inception, and bring your patience "A" game. And don't do this one alone. The real fun with a movie like Primer is discussing it with your friends and family afterwards.

reviewText: Building components in your garage and not knowing what they do - it seems like a bad idea until you create something amazing. And amazing was what was created in the fallout seen in Primer. The explanation is easy enough to give: you have something go into Side A of something and come out Side B when you look at the rules we regularly follow. What if the rules did not apply, however, and what if the thing entering Side A also leaves Side A, pushing aside the constructs of time and crafting a reversal of sorts. It seems endless, like a beautiful thing filled with money and power and promise of the grandest type, until you really think of what could come from creating a truly remarkable breakthrough.You never know who your friends are until you find something to test those waters. Sometimes the adage about you being your own worst enemy - that might possibly be true.I'm not one for the costs of movies, not really impressed with the label "independent" slapped on a shaky project, because movies are movies in the end and many aren't given financial backin. Many genre-specific classics were made on shoestring budgets, and entries like cost sort of fall by the wayside when you look at the end product. While I would not call Primer a classic piece of work, I would call it a great movie and would add that I would have never guessed that it was premiered Independently. The camerawork is great, the acting is really good, and the jargon - despite the use of heavy terminology and dose after dose of wording in speeches that explain things - makes things make sense.And make sense they do.When I first watched Primer I found the movie intriguing as a whole because of the way it played through, and because it gave the viewer an idea and started running with it. It took the idea of time and explained how everything worked, allowing a person to pick up with a couple of friends and continue through a corridor of oddity until...well, until a climax is beautifully rendered. It really got my attention.The reviews on the movie were mixed from the beginning, and the major complaint people had was the heavy use of dialog to substitute action. While I would disagree with that assessment I have to say that was a lot of wordplay here, and if that is a problem then you probably should avoid the movie. If you leave any preconceptions at the door, accepting what the movie tells you, you'll find yourself into a story that makes you want to pause and look over your shoulder because the you yesterday - he might just be a little more ambitious than even you realized.

reviewText: Software engineer-turned-film director Shane Carruth shows one brilliant idea in `Primer': What if you can go back to yesterday, or any time in the past, using a time machine? Usually in the films based on time-traveling idea such as `Back to the Future' series, the time travelers (who go back to the past) do not meet themselves while staying in the past (themselves before time-traveling), and in this way the filmmakers avoid the confusing storytelling process that must follow the consequences of, say, Marty A meeting Marty B. What would happen if Marty in `BTTF' Part 1 looks up, and finds himself Marty in `BTTF' Part 2 looking down at him? Is it possible? If possible, how can you show it on screen, inevitable results affecting the entire series?`Primer' does this brave thing. The low-budget is basically about two young engineers Aaron and Abe who invented a time machine in their small garage. Instead of selling the license of techniques to major company (which I would love to do in their place), Abe and Aaron decide to conceal their invention from the public, and use it to make money. The idea is simple: investment in stock market. Get the right information about the market today, travel back to yesterday, and buy the right ones in the market.But this method inevitably produces (sort of) TWO Aarons and TWO Abes at the same time. It produces `doubles' or `alternatives' of Aaron and Abe. Now here is a question. What if one of the `doubles' starts to act on his own? What if the double gets another `double' using the machine while the original is unaware of his move?The premise sounds incredible, but very intriguing. But for all its fantastic concept, Shane Carruth made one mistake in making the film, and that is the script. To follow what is going on, we need a detailed chart of Abe and Aaron written by someone who can explain all the moves of the two characters, including their `doubles.' One viewing of the film is not enough, perhaps merely allowing you understand the 30 per cent of the story, and that is what happened to me. Now I read the many comments on the net, and that finally became 70 per cent. You might say you have to see the film at least five times. Yes, you are right. But why not make it `three times' or less?`The Primer' uses frequently high-tech jargons, which are slightly off-putting, but that is not a big problem. The film's production designs are frankly amateurish, and the time machine looks like a small box made of brown cardboard, but I can happily ignore those things. But I certainly didn't like sitting as a totally bemused audience in the dark, trying to think, `Is this my fault or not?'I like the film's bleak outlook on the idea of time traveling, and its challenging attitudes to make us think. Shane Carruth has succeeded in doing the latter, I think, for many viewers, including me, still find the mind-bending puzzle very intriguing after watching it. But the puzzle (which is an intelligent one, I admit) could have been better and more refined with more skillful presentation.
summary: Dazzling Time Traveling Thriller: Very Intelligent and Very Confusing

reviewText: There exists a very small genre of movies...12 Monkeys, Memento, The Thing, Basic, Donnie Darko....that DEMAND repeated viewings.  These are movies that with one viewing, you have not enjoyed or understood the majority of the material.  Watching one of these movies is like uncovering a gold mine....you find that there is a wealth, a journey of information and thoughts that you have been invited to and have only just begun.Primer is one of these movies.  I have only seen it once, which nearly makes me unqualified to review it.  I cannot say how well it all fits together yet.  I will say that it makes Memento seem simple at times and promises to keep me thinking for months if not years.Here's the real kicker: 1) Primer was made on a budget of $7000!  2) Every scene was filmed in one take!  3) All of the actors are complete unknown amateurs!You would never guess that any of these three facts are true.  The acting is seamless, the cinematography is often noticeably (in an attention grabbing way) good, and while there aren't any special effects, nothing suggests that this is a low budget film.Like most of the movies I listed at the top, Primer is a movie best viewed without knowing ANYTHING about it.  It has a playful tone of discovery that will be blunted if you have too much knowledge of the plot.Some people have complained that the movie is largely emotionless.  For most of the movie, this is true.  However, the puzzle it creates is engrossing enough that I, for one, felt no lack of emotion.  In fact, the absence of swelling emotions made the film feel much more realistic at times, and I think that may have been the intent.If you like any of the films I mentioned above, don't miss this one.  This isn't the type of movie that mainstream audiences like, so it will never get the recognition it deserves.  I'll be ordering my copy of the movie very soon to support this new Director, Writer, Actor, Composer!
